question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Before this course I knew absolutely nothing about K-Pop. Now I know the history, challenges, politics, and so much more that involves a plethora of idols / groups and could explain it to anyone who asks me.Not only did I learn about the music industry, but I learned about the government and the state of South Korea as a whole, and how it can all be related to K-pop.Finally, I learned to be open-minded. There are so many different ways to spin stories and the way the media twists them is usually for the worst. It's important to do your own research and formulate your opinion on hefty topics, and I learned this from all the political situation that were taking place in the industry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned about the deeper relationship between the evolution of Korean popular music and Korean history and how they mutually influence each other in various aspects.
2. I learned about the various business strategies that Korean entertainment companies would employ to effectively market their groups
3. I learned about how K-pop fans influence not only the success of K-pop groups but also societal issues

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Analytical skills in approaching K-pop. History of K-pop

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to engage with musical lyrics, texts, and performances critically. Additionally, I learned about K-pop's intrinsic relationship with the global world as a whole through South Korea utilizing it as a soft power mechanism. Finally, I learned how to interrogate the influences of K-pop and how the world's geopolitics play into the genre as a whole.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about the musical history of Korea through the lens of Japanese colonization, a lot about the development of big name companies, and themes of race, gender, etc in KPOP

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a great deal about the origins and history of K-pop as a discipline, which was very engaging due to my interest in the topic. I also learned about transculturalism and the concept of cultural hegemony and how Korea and other developed economies play into that media ecosystem. Finally, I learned how people interact with media and why it matters to media stueis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about hte historical orgins of K-pop dating back to the Japanese colonial period in 1920 til present day. I also learned a lot about how to analyze and disect a music video for different aspects such as symbols, aesthetics, and other styles of music videos. I also learned a lot about the modern capitalistic nature of K-pop and the "factory girl" system and cultural production that the K-pop industry utilizes.

response_text: Lectures were thorough and interesting, presentations by students helped solidify knowledge gained by the readings and the lecture. Grading scheme was very diverse (helpful for students) so that one assignment did not make or break the grade.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The course was very informative. Lengthy slideshows followed by interviews and music videos that would relate to the topics we would discuss in class. This form of teaching with discussion followed by real-world examples was a great way to keep students engaged and made it very easy to follow along. I believe all these components should be kept for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructors came up with assignments that allowed students to engage with the class material in a creative and active sense.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Extremely good material choices and fun activities/discussions that facilitated engagement .

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall structure of the course made sense, first going over the history of K-pop and then diving into specific issues. Even though the instructor was relatively new to K-pop herself, she took the time to comprehend it so that the class could be engaged alongside her

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Kim was great at engaging students to the discussion and asking thought-provoking questions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The texts that we read, while long, contributed to my understanding of the nuances of K-pop and the history of the genre which I appreciated.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I loved the lecture style of class! I wish we got to learn more about artists and groups though.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The use of extensive presentations, accountability measures through discussion posts, and a sufficient balance between self-directed exploration and guided class content facilitated my learning by ensuring that I kept up with the class and was able to maintain interest by exploring personally relevant topics.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I thought the class was structured very fairly. Every day I knew exactly what was going to be discussed and what was expected of me. The music video presentation was also really enjoyable and watching everyone else's presentation was really enlightening and enjoyable. I also want to shout out Professor Kim. She wasn't initially supposed to teach the class, but that's how things turned out and you could just tell that she was trying her best to make every class stimulating and enriching despite the subject not being her expertise, so I really appreciate her doing her best for us and creating an interesting space for us to explore K-pop.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The weekly readings and forum posts facilitated our learning as it prepared us for the content that would be covered that week.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The class was stimulating enough as it was. Music is a very core subject for me, so anything that relates to any genre or style of music is automatically interesting. Plus, almost every class we would watch fun and exciting music videos and analyze them throughout the lecture, while also focusing on its social and political impact not only on South Korea but internationally.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The wide range of types of assignments helped the class be a lot more intellectually stimulating than it would have been.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More in class work

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The articles that we were assigned to read every week were very interesting. I also enjoyed the big assignments because half of them were supposed to be fun also

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The discussion question was thought provoking and the readings were really interesting.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Encourage more student engagement by having each student, for example, present a K-pop song to start the class even if it doesn't have anything to do with the topic for the week before getting into the bulk of the lecture-heavy content.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think more hands on activities and watching things in class rather than full lectures.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was intellectually stimulating because of its use of academic techniques to analyze a topic that I found personally entertaining and exciting. question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The topics were simply interesting to me. I am a fan of K-pop, so studying K-pop and different aspects of it in a more scholarly fashion was really enjoyable. I found most of the readings very interesting and the topics we discussed were relevant and interesting as well.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The professor would pose discussion questions which made this class stimulating as it required me to think outside of the box and consider multiple aspects.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Very interesting and intriguing course if you pay attention closely

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Stay on top of your work and don't fall behind. Keep a close look on the syllabus. The beginning of the course may feel like its not all that much work until you realize there are 3 BIG assignments all due by November 30 that you were supposed to have started early on. The professor did mention it in class but not until mid October, whereas there wouldv'e been much more time had you realized in September or August when the class first started. As long as you manage your work and split it out evenly, everything should be okay.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Enjoy and try to stay engaged in the class actively.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Its interesting and fun, but there is a lot of work that doesn't really correspond to the level of the course

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Get ready to do a lot of reading every week

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The class would expand your interest in K-pop through analytical insights

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It was a lot more reading than I expected and not as much music involved, which was disappointing for me. However, I would still recommend it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Super interesting material but decent workload!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would encourage them to take this only if they are passionate about K-pop and are willing to speak their mind in class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This class is definitely a fun course, even if you aren't a fan of K-pop to begin with you can still enjoy learning about the music coming from Korea. The readings aren't too long and the assignments don't take too long either. As long as you show that you put in effort and actually thought about the prompts you will do great in the class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don't think that you need to be an avid K-pop fan in order to take this class. I didn't know much about K-pop before taking this class, but it turned out to be a very fun experience! This course teaches you a lot of the history of K-pop, which is very different to the contemporary K-pop we see and there's fun projects throughout the semester.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about many important foundational elements of African diasporic performance genres, including but not limited to call-and-response and polyrhythms. 
I learned about the ways in which corporeal knowledge is embedded in various performance genres and contains important meanings of identity, cultural preservation, and resistance in the African diaspora. 
Finally, I learned about how various African diasporic performance genres have been co-opted, discredited, and misappropriated by white society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that the body and performance must be recognized as a vital source of knowledge production.I developed skills in thinking about and representing my research in different ways: drawing it out, writing about it in a stream-of-consciousness manner, activating a text I am working with through movement, and more.I adopted the thought process that endings are a social construct and sometimes the work comes to a temporary stopping point, but it is always developing whether you work on it or not. I feel more comfortable with the mentality that things will always be unfinished and I can always return to them when inspiration strikes again.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How the body has been ignored and forgotten in much of academic scholarship and how the written word has and still dominates what knowledge is valued (Spatz, Foster, Hartman)
How power is subverted and claimed in ways that the colonial gaze misses or misconstrues  (Mahmood, Taylor)
How scholars, artists, and ourselves are challenging notions of objective, rational fact as truth ~ bringing in creative writing, movement, performance and interdisciplinary thinking into our work

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The text activations were extremely effective in my engagement with each text. The first one we did felt like enough. If we had done two, I think it may have been too much.I was especially engaged with the text activation about the punching, slashing, floating, etc. that Professor Wilbur offered. It was an incredibly useful visual that I return to when thinking about my word choices and each position I take in a paper.I really appreciated the alteration of the classroom setup. It was mentally stimulating to sit in a new spot every day and it helped me get connected to other students in class.The accountability structure for the final project was well-timed for me. I grew more comfortable with sharing work in the development stages, which I feel made my paper stronger.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had to develop a lot of listening skills. Professor Richard is a lecturer and does not have many slides, so I had to work on my listening comprehension skills to pick up the class. I also learned to write several large papers in French. I had to put a lot of effort into writing my papers with both good analyses and proper comprehension. We had a giant presentation in the semester, so I had to work on my presentation skills and be able to teach the class in French for half an hour. I had never talked for that long before, so this was a challenge.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

- I learned how to write in depth analyses in french

response_text:
I learned how to compare and analyze different methods of media.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This was the first class at Duke where simply speaking French did not get me out of having to think. I learned how to better relate concepts across languages, time periods, and cultural attitudes at the time. I learned how to incorporate media into my studies and use them as a primary source to attitudes of expression while also analyzing them as means to showcase royal power and authority.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I gained significant insight into the history of Versailles, particularly as it relates to the development of the arts and influence on music within the seventh century into the present day. I learned about the different conflicts in the context of the French Opera, Ballet, and Theatre which helped me understand the existence of these institutions in modern-day France as well as how and why they mattered to the shifting power structures in the region in the last few centuries. I have been able to develop more nuanced analytical thinking skills in the realm of French history which, in turn, has deepened my appreciation for the main figures associated with that history.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about cognition and the effect of subcortical white matter fiber tracts in aging. I learned how working memory affects consciousness. I learned about embodied cognition and ecological validity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course touches on the foundations of neuroscience research and neuroimaging, with a particular focus on cognitive reserve. To understand the research, knowledge of how fMRI, EEG, MEG, and CSM were taught, as well as foundational principles like the basis of resting state fMRI and a multimodal theory of the brain. The course also delved into some linguistic theory and conversations about language and consciousness, as well as music and musicianship. A lot of the neuroscience research that we looked at was situated in the context of languaging and musicianship.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I used critical thinking and expanded my vocabulary when it came to discussing new terms related to latinX studies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The small seminar class has helped facilitate various conversations that reflected some of the feelings of the students in the class. Majority of us have some sort of tie to Latin America and being able to talk about and relate to common experiences we have faced has been very validating. I also loved having the service aspect of the class. Getting out of the "Duke bubble" to engage with the Latinx Durham community was fulfilling and helped me create ties to a new community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned lots about different kinds of Latin American music, political movements, and the story behind words like Latinidad or ones that are equally or even more controversial like Malinche.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the course, I developed critical thinking skills when examining labels and concepts like Latino and Latinidad. I learned about the history of the Latinx community in the United States and gained insight into issues like discrimination and assimilation that followed mass migration. I learned about the relevance of music in Latinx culture and thought about the many ways it can be used to express and explore culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Coming into the class, I had some pretty big assumptions about the general content of the class. At first, I didn't think the course was going to center on US Latinx studies; I thought it was
going to focus on the history of Latin American countries and how those become affected by US intervention. Personally, I truly enjoy the direction the course is going. Learning about the history
of Latinos in the US, their struggles, their legacy, is a rich topic that I had previously not had the resources to understand. I've always wanted to learn more about this but I've never really had
the impetus to do so. I think it is so interesting to talk about these historical events, like the Chicano movement or the labor strikes, and tell my friends about them. It's a part of history that
goes unnoticed and it's worthy of bringing up everyone once in a while during a conversation. Outside of that, I feel like this class has made me more conscious of the continual Latino
presence in the US and what people are doing to combat injustice. I've done research and learned about powerful organizations, both in North Carolina and my hometown of Miami. It's
amazing seeing that everywhere there are communities like these all fighting for visibility and justice. I gain a lot from the music component of the course, and connect it to other music classes I've
taken at Duke. It's interesting seeing the connection between how the music we study is composed and what the music is representing. Understanding the Chicano movement through
song is a beautiful way to look at history. A song I particularly found touching was "Urbano's song". It was by far one of the saddest songs I've heard this year, and I still listen to it in my
 spare time.More concisely I learned:
- How to analyze Latino history and research topics in Latino studies.
- How to make a community facing project 
- How service learning can be used to supplement a class as well as engage with the surrounding community.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This class was awesome! Emily's enthusiasm for the class and the material is evident and contagious. She was an incredibly approachable, flexible, and caring professor and created an environment where it felt like we were really able to think critically while also having fun in a low-stakes environment. The course's selected topics and the sequence in which these topics were presented were logical and coherent. I appreciated that Emily took the time to contextualize each new topic we discussed within the scope of what we had learned thus far. Topics were well-connected and referenced each other, which gave me a deeper appreciation for the course's ethnomusicological lens and each of the individual musics. Emily did a fantastic job of fostering a friendly and supportive class environment. Despite the larger class size, it felt like we were able to have discussions, share ideas, and get to know each other's ways of thinking. Emily also seemed genuinely interested in learning from us, fostering a non-hierarchical classroom environment (versus one where the professor clearly presents as the all-knowing expert uninterested in students' insights) that I think greatly encouraged students' independent thinking. Karaoke was a lot of fun and also helped build camaraderie among the class. I think all of the assignments were meaningful and useful while also leaving plenty of room for our own thinking and creativity (e.g. 3 you pick listening journals and a very open-ended final project). Course assignments were structured in a way that leaves options and appeals to a diversity of strengths and weaknesses (e.g. appealing to those who prefer test-taking vs. essay-writing and to those who prefer independent vs group work). Most of all, this class was fun! It's such a relief to have a class that is genuinely fun, where the professor is also excited to just have fun while still learning a lot.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked how much music we had to listen to. The listening reflection/listening journal was really fun, because it's pretty informal but still requires a level of understanding of musicology concepts. Final project is fun and I like Prof Wang's openness to all sorts of projects.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take it -- no matter if you are Asian or speak any Asian language. From the modern pop music in Asia (well, East Asia to be more exact) and Asian America, you actually learn tremendously about the historical reason behind why certain music sounds like a certain way coming from these countries and cultures, and it's a methodology extremely applicable to analyzing the music of other geographies -- we do a lot of cross cultural analysis in music beyond just Asian music as well.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Prof. Kelley was exceptionally engaged in the topic of the course and it was immediately clear to the students who came to class that he loves soul music and knows a lot about the musicology behind it. He mixed in lecture components with singing, playing on the piano, and audiovisual elements that were helpful to contextualize the media we were talking about. He also made clear the differences between different types of soul and made it clear to us what we would be quizzed on and how.

response_text: He encouraged us to try singing, clapping, and playing instruments in and outside of class, which took us outside of our comfort zone as non music majors. This was essential for our learning.For the Motown section of the class, it was extremely important for me to read about the history of Motown's founder, Barry Gordy, to get the context behind the music. This helped me be invested in learning the songs and their meanings.

It's important to do your own research and formulate your opinion on hefty topics, and I learned this from all the political situation that were taking place in the industry.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The instructor was very open to our opinions, and assumed no prior knowledge of music theory - which I think was very effective, since most of the students were interested in music, but not necessarily musicians.
He also prepared interesting materials (videos of musician interviews, performances, music videos) that would open up discussion.
The other effective component was assignments, which encouraged us to attend on-campus musical events, which I would never have found out about it before. The final assignment, making and presenting the playlist, was also very interesting and helpful.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Professor Heid has done a great job of influencing the way I practice, as of late. He also has emphasized that learning the piano happens at your own pace and some information may finally be registered even years later. He also has taught me resilience through difficult pieces, especially this semester.

Mr Heid, tailors his lessons very well to what needs looking at adapting what we will work on as we go. I think Mr Heid also finds a very good balance with keeping students encouraged whilst challenging them. The piano can often be challenging and, at times, uninspiring, but to progress one needs to persist through slight lulls of inspiration. Mr Heid makes classes very fun and reassures during them, keeping morale and inspiration high.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:

- Breathing low takes less effort, and thus is more effective than trying to breathe through the chest
- There is a "slip joint" in the back of the jaw that is a good indicator of how far to open the mouth during long vowels.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. L facilitated my learning by helping me better visualize what was happening in my body when I breathe--not just on a practical/anatomy level, but also with visuals and images I can imagine to help me feel these techniques. I'd love to continue this wholistic type of learning when I have both an anatomy/practical understanding of what's happening in my body, as well as visualizations. In addition to this, I love when Dr. L has me sing my songs with different ideas in my head--whether it be "pretend you're angry!" or "sing this like you are an old proper lady" etc. It makes the lessons fun, and helps me realize specific techniques. I also like the exercises she gives me on the printed out sheet. Those are helpful in my own, individual practice.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a new comedic opera, Mozart's Der Schauspieldirektor. Specifically, we learned the finale, and I learned the part of Bluff. The part involved transposing a solo (since the part is originally for a male voice), singing in my lower range and exploring flipping across two registers, doing more character development and staging than I have ever done before, and doing dialogue (acting) and silent reactionary stage work. I learned to step outside my comfort zone and embrace the sassiness/extravagance/flamboyance of my character and the scene as a whole. I also noticed myself becoming more comfortable with performance anxiety.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. importance of overacting
2. sing out! do not compromise too much in opera (if I sing louder others will do too)
3. spacing out on stage

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned performance practice, acting, and historical details about a specific opera: the Marriage of Figaro.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

Knowledge of operatic repertoire

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: David did a great job in leading rehearsals and providing great notes after every run of our scene. He was very understanding with us taking a little while to learn and memorize the material, but he constantly pushed us to be the best performers and singers we could be.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: We met weekly to rehearse, gradually moving from running notes and rhythms, to running staging with memorized music, and finally to the dress rehearsals and show. I thought the semester progressed at a good place, and I had something to practice/perfect on my own every week, so that when I came to rehearsal, we could tackle new issues. David really encouraged me to step outside my comfort zone and embody my over-the-top character. I really appreciated his constructive feedback and support throughout the whole semester. I also appreciated that we started rehearsing in Baldwin earlier in the semester and had two dress rehearsals. And I loved that the scenes were longer (~20 mins each) with costumes/props/sets.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Opera Theater is in most regards a "light" version of being in a play -- less time committed, but still the same kind of work and chances to bond as an ensemble. It's a great way to explore classical singing beyond voice lessons. From observing performances, I would suggest that the stagecraft taught in Opera Theater is noticeably more fundamentally sound than that displayed in some theater department productions.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Friedman is very knowledgeable and approachable. Even though he takes Chorale very seriously, he goes about our rehearsals lightheartedly to make it fun for us. He also uses our rehearsals as learning spaces for other aspects of our music. When he had his choral conducting students conduct us, it was a great experience conducting for them, but it was also a great experience for us to not be under Dr. Friedman's baton constantly and have to adapt to any mistakes that are made.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: There was an expectation to come to rehearsal prepared, so we could use our time wisely, which I thought was stimulating and every rehearsal felt important.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was stimulating because we were able to take breaks and talk to people in the choir! There were also specific event s organized to ensure that is continued. I also loved the music we sang!!

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Leaning challenging music made this class stimulating. emotionally complex music in various languages and styles was very stimulating to learn as well as complex harmonies and dynamics

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Music is in of itself stimulating, but, as with any ensemble, learning the music and crafting a high-quality performance can be tedious... that's just how the music world is. Much of the stimulation I got was from the variety of pieces that we sang. When we sung Eric Whitacre's "Sacred Veil", the deep connections of this piece to our loved ones who have passed made this piece emotionally difficult yet rewarding to sing. Learning smaller pieces is great to put together cohesive concerts quickly, but it's these experiences that I get the most from, personally.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Take it! Allan is amazing you won’t find a better conductor who cares about the music and the musician.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Have fun!!! Dr. Friedman is the best.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Chorale feels much more like a club than a course, but the commitment is about what you would expect from the credits. (3hr rehearsal/wk + practice + lots of concerts) That being said, if you're looking for a performance experience that is not an a cappella group, you're in the right place! Dr. Friedman is a wonderful conductor who will put in the effort to get to know you and help you succeed in the Chorale space.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: The way this class is structured right now is for performers who are looking to improve upon their performance skills. This class doesn't feel like an elective, so if your intention is to have fun singing and not think about technical skills and theory, you should find a different singing or acting class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: unless you really like making music videos there may be better theater workshop classes in terms of the curriculum plan.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Chauntee' does not give A- or B+, etc.. She does only A, B, C, and D, so if you get below a 93, that's where the B begins. Just be aware because there are only five assignments, each worth 20 points, so you can't get off more than seven points total or else you'll get a B. 
There is also a research project towards the beginning of the semester that takes a substantial amount of time. You may not be told that you have to memorize a song for the performance part of that project, but if you bring in sheet music and refer to it when you sing, you will get points off. Prepare your song as if it's an audition. In your music video project, don't deviate from your previously-submitted plan without talking to Chauntee' first, as you will get points off if your final product is different than your plan.
Chauntee' gives good feedback on singing and acting, so I enjoyed working with her overall.

- The effects of government subsidization and other funding sources on arts production
- Evaluating art from both a disciplinary and personal perspective (and combining those two perspectives into ethnographic research)

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me so many useful skills, whether I decide to be a production manager for theater or not. Through the books we read, like Dan Heath's Upstream and Fearless Negotiating by Michael C. Donaldson, I learned how to preemptively stop problems from occurring, as well as how to negotiate and the most effective way to do so. Through our assignments, I learned how to organize and put together a calendar with important dates and events, as well as how to make a budget for both mainstage and repertory theater shows, which is a very useful skill. Knowing how to work with money and budget everything accurately is a skill important to all aspects of life.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: That the class is is a lot of outside work which may be cumbersome if you also have a class that eats up a lot of your time. Overall though, if you have any interest in theater or management the class is very interesting. If you have no background in theater the class does cover most of what you would need to know. The knowledge gained from the class can be applicable in areas outside of theater as well, so it is still worthwhile. The class is pretty chill and Thom is very approachable, plus you get to enjoy two comped shows, one at the DPAC with a Q&A session with the cast and crew after, and another with the Duke Theater Studies Show. Additionally, Thom lines up a good selection of guest speakers with quality inside knowledge and stories which were interesting every time. For those reasons I recommend the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
I learned about many important foundational elements of African diasporic performance genres, including but not limited to call-and-response and polyrhythms. 
I learned about the ways in which corporeal knowledge is embedded in various performance genres and contains important meanings of identity, cultural preservation, and resistance in the African diaspora. 
Finally, I learned about how various African diasporic performance genres have been co-opted, discredited, and misappropriated by white society.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about public policy which was something I hadn't focused on here at Duke.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot about what arts policy was, from the history of it to how it relates to my everyday life. I also learned great project-based skills like time management and communication. Furthermore, I learned how to write a policy brief, which is something I didn't know how to do before.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Critical analysis of policies and institutions - i.e. considering how institutions are created and situated, and how this impacts the people attracted to this institution and how that institution is perceived

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I was able to build knowledge in U.S. public policy, art and the intersection of both in a very engaging and practical way.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned a lot of subtle, overlooked concepts. Creative placemaking, the interplay of public/private/non-profit institutions, and this is the biggest thing: a greater appreciation of arts institutions & events around me. Before this class, I really didn't look to go to museums or art exhibits or dance performances. However, my positive experiences with these aforementioned things have motivated me to go to more events around campus and Durham. I think this is most notable with the performances in Page Auditorium. I will also say this course has helped me network/ reach out when working with my community partner. This was especially relevant when I wanted to include an extra component in the project and I had to gather the resources/data from different teams in the organization and outside.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Understanding of public arts policy decision-making

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about what exactly is arts policy, various cultural institutions and its issues, leadership and value in the arts, cultural equity (audience and access, heritage and repatriation), creative placemaking, and creative economies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: We reviewed case studies in arts leadership, visited local cultural organizations, and discussed the challenges facing the arts today. A central component of the course was the extended engagement with a community partner, so we developed our collaborative skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to think about art in a different and new context. I also learned professional skills through the service learning aspect of the course.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about cultural and arts policies, and how we can observe the phenomenons of these policies in real life. I gained insight on the impacts of cultural and arts policy, and how each action affects the communities around us.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. Learned more about all different aspects of art policy

3. How to collaborate professionally in a workplace

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Specifically I learned how to analysis and interpret arts policy in the real world today and apply my leadership knowledge in unique ways to make a difference both in Durham and my local community here at Duke. I learned how to critically engage with peers about arts policy and discuss with them. Lastly, I learned how to work with community partners to ensure long-term success.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The absolute free-for-all structure of the discussions really helped me open up. This is very dependent on the people in the class, though. question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: This course is probably the most impactful class I have taken at Duke because I learned and experienced so much. We were put into group projects to help with a specific arts organization, where we gained so much insight on what it is like to help with arts administration as well as policy. We also went on multiple class excursions that allowed us to understand how the audience interacts with the art institutions, as well as our experience with it. Everything in this course- especially the content- was so meaningful and important for me to learn about.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The biggest stimulating factor were the fieldtrips & the semester long project. They were more dynamic and allowed us to incorporate a lot of skills we personally had. It gave us an organization or community to reach out to, which helped. I think tying the fieldtrips back to the concepts we learned was enlightening. This was most seen in the writing assignments, such as the discussion posts. There was a lot of critical thinking and realization that "oh yeah, this particular institution shows a concept we highlighted in class" or "I did not even realize this institution probably had to mull over their economics & that this affected their policy." I think the final paper was kind of shoved in there at the end, but I much prefer that over any final exam.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: In the course, I developed critical thinking skills when examining labels and concepts like Latino and Latinidad. I learned about the history of the Latinx community in the United States and gained insight into issues like discrimination and assimilation that followed mass migration. I learned about the relevance of music in Latinx culture and thought about the many ways it can be used to express and explore culture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Coming into the class, I had some pretty big assumptions about the general content of the class. At first, I didn't think the course was going to center on US Latinx studies; I thought it was
going to focus on the history of Latin American countries and how those become affected by US intervention. Personally, I truly enjoy the direction the course is going. Learning about the history
of Latinos in the US, their struggles, their legacy, is a rich topic that I had previously not had the resources to understand. I've always wanted to learn more about this but I've never really had
the impetus to do so. I think it is so interesting to talk about these historical events, like the Chicano movement or the labor strikes, and tell my friends about them. It's a part of history that
goes unnoticed and it's worthy of bringing up everyone once in a while during a conversation. Outside of that, I feel like this class has made me more conscious of the continual Latino
presence in the US and what people are doing to combat injustice. I've done research and learned about powerful organizations, both in North Carolina and my hometown of Miami. It's
amazing seeing that everywhere there are communities like these all fighting for visibility and justice. I gain a lot from the music component of the course, and connect it to other music classes I've
taken at Duke. It's interesting seeing the connection between how the music we study is composed and what the music is representing. Understanding the Chicano movement through
song is a beautiful way to look at history. A song I particularly found touching was "Urbano's song". It was by far one of the saddest songs I've heard this year, and I still listen to it in my
 spare time.More concisely I learned:
- How to analyze Latino history and research topics in Latino studies.
- How to make a community facing project 
- How service learning can be used to supplement a class as well as engage with the surrounding community.

Finally, this class has truly changed my understanding of jazz, especially the more subtle interdisciplinary connections between subjects like musical expression, music theory, American history, and pop culture. Taking this course has given me a much better idea of what jazz is foremost, and has also allowed me the means to appreciate the cultural and historical factors that have inspired what it's become today.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- The development of Beethoven's style, it's divergence from Classical tradition, and how that relates to the stylistic characteristics of the works of Beethoven's contemporaries.
- As the Romantic Era progressed, how some composers deviated tangentially from convention to create something new (i.e. Berlioz and caricaturing) while others were "Janus-faced" with an eye on both the future and the past (i.e. Brahms and Mendelssohn, often dubbed as the two Classic-Romantics)
- How pioneering elements of late-Romantic composers (i.e. Liszt's Faust Symphony) led to both Schoenberg's experiments in atonality and French Modernism/Impressionism in intertwining paths.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Characteristics of Romantic-era music as well as several composers across the century

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Classicism vs. romanticism, Russian 19th century composers, the beginnings of modernism

response_text: The course was overall not very stressful, as Dr. Todd focused on the students' experiences rather than the letter grade, which he tried to avoid spending class time on. I observed that this was a bit much for some of my colleagues, but I liked this approach since I could focus on conveying my understanding on assignments rather than fulfilling strict requirements on a rubric. Classes were held in a classic lecture format, which I think worked well with Dr. Todd's teaching style, as he was able to keep the class interesting with his plethora of knowledge.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Don’t take it unless you really have to. Absolutely don’t think it as a GPA booster because it’s absolutely not and quite on the contrary, it pulls it down no matter how hard you study for it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Clarity seems to be a persistent issue with the course. Until Professor Todd resolves these issues, I cannot recommend you take it with him, even with as much as I enjoyed his lectures and have respect for him as a musicologist. The good news is that the issues I have presented are objective and easy to fix (every other MH course does them). I am optimistic that these points may not be issues in future class sessions.That said if you must take it with him, the way to do well on the assessments is to rely heavily on a music theory analysis and tie those elements into a historical context (do not write about history and just describe how the piece makes you feel). Avoid using vague language and avoid writing your papers the day before due to allow time to find grammatical/redundancy errors. If you do these things, it should be possible to get an A-/A on every paper.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Enjoy the course, but spend time on the papers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Even if you don't plan on minoring/majoring in music, I would highly recommend this course! You will learn a lot about Romantic music regardless of your background and with someone who is deeply passionate about his life's work. That being said, go into the class thinking about this rather than the quantitative grade or course credits that you get out of it—Dr. Todd purposely doesn't mention these a lot, and he likes focusing on your experience in his class a lot more. You will get the most out of your experience if you ask questions during class and talk to him afterwards. Don't be afraid of being wrong—just be curious!

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Professor Todd is incredibly knowledgeable on practically anything you pick his brain on. He’s a wealth of knowledge and is very amenable to students. The papers aren’t too difficult - just be sure to proofread beforehand. Utilize the music library, as there are many books down in the stacks that will help give you accurate positions on the pieces for the papers. The listening quizzes are only tough because the pieces are very long (multiple symphonies with multiple movements). Be sure to take it chunk by chunk and start very early in advance so you don’t have to stress about cramming beforehand.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Listening quizzes aren't that difficult. Mostly just pay attention to the specific excerpts played in class, take notes on potentially what to listen for, and memorize the years (also if you start studying early it's also easier, although I did well on both just by cramming the night before and the day of the exam). Papers on the other hand are difficult and seem to be graded very heavily on clarity and conciseness of writing, use of varied word choice, and consistency of formatting, so spend some time editing your papers.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

So try and have a draft of each project the week before it is due.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: If you want to make good music, it’s going to take time. It took me hours upon hours just to come up with an idea. I am not a music major, but I have played piano my whole life. Anyone who is looking to make EDM/pop music in the class should honestly have a basic music background as finding harmonys and playing in key would be difficult for someone with zero music knowledge.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course was one of the most valuable courses I have taken in my time at Duke. To me this class has been the equivalent of a musical public speaking class. During my time in this class, I have learned to prepare music and a lesson plan for a group to sing, how to think on the fly on how to engage a choir and develop a piece, and I have learned proper conducting etiquette. This class has also helped me to become a better, stronger leader overall through my developed group leading and communication skills.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed leadership skills by learning how to direct a choral rehearsal in all its components, including the act of conducting, planning spots to go over, and managing time. I also learned to conduct confidently enough to focus on more expressive aspects of the music, such as dynamics, phrasing, and word stresses. Additionally, I practiced giving both positive and constructive feedback to my peers and learned to focus on the music while watching my peer's gesture.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The mechanics of conducting, how to run a rehearsal, and how to work collaboratively with an ensemble + accompanist.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to effectively lead a group choral rehearsal, how to convey musical ideas via gesture, and how to work with other professionals in the choral music space.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about conducting patterns, choral warm ups, rehearsal techniques

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Friedman provides a very welcoming and nurturing learning environment for his class. The class is comprised of singers from groups throughout Duke and even one person who conducts in band but doesn't sing otherwise. Dr. Friedman's hands on approach to the class helped each student to improve through their active participation as we are always getting in front of the group to practice our conducting. I would definitely keep this component for future years. The guest speakers he brings in offer different point of views to conducting and music making as a whole which I have found great value from.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The overall learning environment of this class was incredibly welcoming and positive. I looked forward to this class every Tuesday and Thursday, and was grateful for the musical and social outlet it provided in the midst of days that were sometimes long and stressful. The routine of the group singing for one person conducting was fun and helpful, as we got practice both conducting and learning large quantities of music, so I would keep that structure for future years. Furthermore, the final exam was a great culmination of everything we learned this semester, from the actual motions of conducting to planning and running a rehearsal, so I would keep the final exam component the same for future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Professor Friedman is extremely welcoming and kind. The structure of the class sessions is perfect I would repeat this in future years.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I think prioritizing podium time was a good choice for the class. I also liked the addition of outside speakers that brought different perspectives on conducting and various aspects of music.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?

One thing that could be done to make the course even more intellectually stimulating is to start each class with a short conducting exercise, such as the exercise we did at the beginning of the semester where we told each other different dynamics/tempos and went around in a circle.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

I learned about the different conflicts in the context of the French Opera, Ballet, and Theatre which helped me understand the existence of these institutions in modern-day France as well as how and why they mattered to the shifting power structures in the region in the last few centuries. I have been able to develop more nuanced analytical thinking skills in the realm of French history which, in turn, has deepened my appreciation for the main figures associated with that history.

Taking this course is a great opportunity expand upon a creative practice (including creative research practices) from the standpoint of generativity (whether your interest is in in-the-box computational generativity or another mode of system-based creative production).
