question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Spatialization of sound and storytelling for sound; orientation to an analog mixer, basic physics of sound, QLab, Reaper, dynamics, sound system plotting for live performance.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This class was very useful when it came to certain programming and tech practice, particularly QLab and working with mixers. The time we spent scoring scripts was also an excellent learning opportunity for theatrical sound design.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-Learning how to use an audio mixer
-Learning Reaper as a DAW
-Experimentation and use of QLab to craft sound design for scenes
-System-thinking on how to manipulate sound to give a desired effect
-Punctuation, concrete vs. abstract, time manipulation, and other techniques for sound design
-Collaboration on final project involving live and digital instruments and sounds

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: A wide range of techniques in Reaper and Qlab to produce blended sound effects and theatrical sonic cues, as well as the important concepts in theatrical sonic design.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
sound software
sound theory
sound practice

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-Learned QLab and Reaper
-Developed skills in how to create a story that can be understood only through sound
-Became more familiar with sound design language such as punctuation, foley, ambience, etc.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I feel the workshops/critiques were really valuable since we were such a small class -- and fostered a shared ethos/community.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The frequent, smaller assignments towards the beginning of the semester were very useful, as was the QLab skills quiz. The Deiorio and the Music as a Chariot readings were both great for engagement out of class, and I wish we had been assigned more of them. Scoring the Jekyll and Hyde script multiple times was also great.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
-Ethan knows his craft and is able to teach it in a variety of ways using hands-on technology as well as with readings and at-home assignments.
-OH are helpful for getting up to speed if behind or with asking questions re: DAW or QLab use.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Great. This is the only class I have this semester that I feel unstressed to speak up anytime. I like the one-by-one display of weekly assignments and the following peer feedback session. This section really opens up the floor for discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Course is well constructed

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
-QLab tutorials were very helpful. I would suggest assigning them as homework rather than going through it as a class. It was difficult to grasp until I actually did it myself
-The variety in the assignments was engaging - using an existing story, using only sound, making speaker plots, etc.
-The midterm was a great checkpoint for my technical skills

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The spatialization of sound, especially in live performance was challenging and inspiring.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More readings and out of class work! More skills quizzes! The topics were all incredibly stimulating, and because we were covering such a broad field of knowledge, I felt we could have been given more of a challenge to chew on in order to cover more of that field. More listening opportunities might also have been useful, maybe a mandatory field trip to a show or having student presentations on shows they'd been to?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
-Music creation and sound adaptation were stimulating aspects of the class.
-Sound designing for scripts like Jekyll & Hyde was a fun and interesting experience.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: In-class discussions and feedback from my classmates. Also, I like the context-fixed creative assignments that allow me to apply some techniques in several unexpected situations, such as transformation moments in the hyde script.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The book is very educational

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
-The student presentations of the assignments many of the weeks taking all of class was not very stimulating. I felt disengaged after a few people went. If it were a shorter amount of class time or only a few people present each week, I think it would be more engaging
-I would have appreciated more instructor lectures on the technical and conceptual decisions in sound design, especially in the beginning of the semester
-Bringing us into the theater for the show was super engaging and I learned a lot being in the actual theater space

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's good! A course that is unique and teaches unique invaluable skills and asks you to think and make creatively. So grateful for this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
-Good for theatrical sound design, as in the title!
-You learn what you put into it. If heavily invested, a lot. If less so, then you will still learn a good amount and it will change your perception of theatre when you experience it live.

response_text: JUST TAKE IT!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze scientific papers in the fields of neuroscience, music, and linguistics, write scientific research papers using sources, and think critically.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
What speech acts are, structure of language
Music's effects on the brain
How neuroimaging works and how this research is done

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to do research, more neuroscience topics, and properties of sound

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned about cognition and the effect of subcortical white matter fiber tracts in aging. I learned how working memory affects consciousness. I learned about embodied cognition and ecological validity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course touches on the foundations of neuroscience research and neuroimaging, with a particular focus on cognitive reserve. To understand the research, knowledge of how fMRI, EEG, MEG, and CSM were taught, as well as foundational principles like the basis of resting state fMRI and a multimodal theory of the brain. The course also delved into some linguistic theory and conversations about language and consciousness, as well as music and musicianship. A lot of the neuroscience research that we looked at was situated in the context of languaging and musicianship.

response_text: I liked the small classes and the conversational class environment. I think having more student instruction would be better.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Andrews's whole philosophy is that students should take something out of a course, and the course is structured around just that. From the way the homeworks work to the way she writes her exams (with no wrong information presented), she is entirely focused on student outcomes.

response_text: Great readings, great papers that are very insightful

response_text: The discussion aspect and the professor's knowledge on the subject.

response_text: It was very stimulating and the required homework made us engage with the material and ensured student participation.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Definitely take this course! It is a lot of work and reading but is extremely rewarding in the end and I am so glad I was able to learn from Dr. Andrews.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Do the readings and participate in class

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Enjoy, put it in the effort and try to meet with her early and multiple times for the final project

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Edna was excellent. Her care and compassion exceeds so many professors. She is a wonderful professor and one I would recommend to anyone. She is delightful and a gem in the Duke professor environment. Anyone in her class is lucky to experience her light.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This was an amazing course. The workload is not too challenging, and the payoff is enormous. As I was researching articles for my final paper, I found that I could sit down and read an entire neuroscience article start to finish and understand what was going on. This is especially amazing to me because I am not a neuroscience or psych major, so all of the concepts in this class were new to me. Dr. Andrews is also an amazing professor, and she is always excited to hear what students will do and say.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: The importance of bodily knowledge, body and mind connection, the body is a living archive, the body can transmit culture, dance scholars, scholarly writing.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- Thinking of historiography from the perspective of bodies and included/excluded narratives

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned that the body and performance must be recognized as a vital source of knowledge production.I developed skills in thinking about and representing my research in different ways: drawing it out, writing about it in a stream-of-consciousness manner, activating a text I am working with through movement, and more.I adopted the thought process that endings are a social construct and sometimes the work comes to a temporary stopping point, but it is always developing whether you work on it or not. I feel more comfortable with the mentality that things will always be unfinished and I can always return to them when inspiration strikes again.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
How the body has been ignored and forgotten in much of academic scholarship and how the written word has and still dominates what knowledge is valued (Spatz, Foster, Hartman)
How power is subverted and claimed in ways that the colonial gaze misses or misconstrues  (Mahmood, Taylor)
How scholars, artists, and ourselves are challenging notions of objective, rational fact as truth ~ bringing in creative writing, movement, performance and interdisciplinary thinking into our work

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The reading discussions were top notch.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The text activations were extremely effective in my engagement with each text. The first one we did felt like enough. If we had done two, I think it may have been too much.I was especially engaged with the text activation about the punching, slashing, floating, etc. that Professor Wilbur offered. It was an incredibly useful visual that I return to when thinking about my word choices and each position I take in a paper.I really appreciated the alteration of the classroom setup. It was mentally stimulating to sit in a new spot every day and it helped me get connected to other students in class.The accountability structure for the final project was well-timed for me. I grew more comfortable with sharing work in the development stages, which I feel made my paper stronger.

Readings were awesome overall!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. There is a big difference between ethnomusicological account of ethnography and an ethnography of Anthropology of music.
2. There are multiple ways to think of absence other than sonic absences.
3. Ethnomusicological ethnographies.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: diverse forms of absence and study culture musically, such as haunting, ghosting, death, memory, unseen, invisibility, harmonization, religious presence, sensational knowledge, and so forth.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1. I learned the relationship between absence and political presence. The political presence is the power to conduct an archival form of absence, whether its intentional or non-intentional, spoken or unspoken, all related back to “who” and the following factors of “why and how they embodied/non-embodied themself.” This “who,” including Scholars, archivers, employees, white ants, administrators, and officers were all forming their own political presence through sense-making and making sense in their “here and now.”2. Communication techniques: I learned how to combine different dimensions and elements of academic thoughts to weave a productive conversation.3. Teaching Method: I am very impressed with how an entirely respectful space could open such deep and diverse interactions in the class. Having in-person conversations with visiting scholars was also a great way to learn more about different perspectives and reflect on my own research.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I developed a better sense on how hard and slippery it is to conceptualize silence and absence. I think that what it means to be human and how humans based their identity depends as much on those two terms as in others more popular for such issues.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: 1) I've learned to think of silence and quietude —and by extension, of sound—differently. In the logocentric paradigm that is prevalent in the Euro-American world, only speech is understood as a way of proper resistance or as a site of potentiality, and silence is understood as a lack/deficiency/sign of powerlessness. But the works we read in this class tell another story. In these works, silence can be a site of potentiality, too. Silence can be a powerful form of sociality, a form of care, or the rhythm of life. I've also learned about how some perform listening through erasure/archival absence/untold stories and unsaid words.2) this course reshape my understanding of the theoretical, especially in relation to the ordinary/the everyday and in relation to story-telling. I've realized that theories can take many forms and theories can be stories too.3) i've learnt to attend to the sonic dimension of things and become more attentive to sounds, voices, listening, and silences.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
The instructor adopted a diverse perspective when designing the weekly discussion topics for the class, rather than confining the themes to existing academic contexts and frameworks. Additionally, the instructor's selection of reading materials was not limited to the field of ethnomusicology, which greatly facilitated exploring different dimensions of thought.
I will keep these two principles for future years.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
Chauntee' does not give A- or B+, etc.. She does only A, B, C, and D, so if you get below a 93, that's where the B begins. Just be aware because there are only five assignments, each worth 20 points, so you can't get off more than seven points total or else you'll get a B. 
There is also a research project towards the beginning of the semester that takes a substantial amount of time. You may not be told that you have to memorize a song for the performance part of that project, but if you bring in sheet music and refer to it when you sing, you will get points off. Prepare your song as if it's an audition. In your music video project, don't deviate from your previously-submitted plan without talking to Chauntee' first, as you will get points off if your final product is different than your plan.
Chauntee' gives good feedback on singing and acting, so I enjoyed working with her overall.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course taught me so many useful skills, whether I decide to be a production manager for theater or not. Through the books we read, like Dan Heath's Upstream and Fearless Negotiating by Michael C. Donaldson, I learned how to preemptively stop problems from occurring, as well as how to negotiate and the most effective way to do so. Through our assignments, I learned how to organize and put together a calendar with important dates and events, as well as how to make a budget for both mainstage and repertory theater shows, which is a very useful skill. Knowing how to work with money and budget everything accurately is a skill important to all aspects of life.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to use excel, budgeting for up to four productions at a time, film. budgeting, theater budgeting, what a production manager is, communication styles, upstream/downstream thinking.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: That the class is is a lot of outside work which may be cumbersome if you also have a class that eats up a lot of your time. Overall though, if you have any interest in theater or management the class is very interesting. If you have no background in theater the class does cover most of what you would need to know. The knowledge gained from the class can be applicable in areas outside of theater as well, so it is still worthwhile. The class is pretty chill and Thom is very approachable, plus you get to enjoy two comped shows, one at the DPAC with a Q&A session with the cast and crew after, and another with the Duke Theater Studies Show. Additionally, Thom lines up a good selection of guest speakers with quality inside knowledge and stories which were interesting every time. For those reasons I recommend the class.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
-Learned QLab and Reaper
-Developed skills in how to create a story that can be understood only through sound
-Became more familiar with sound design language such as punctuation, foley, ambience, etc.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I feel the workshops/critiques were really valuable since we were such a small class -- and fostered a shared ethos/community.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The frequent, smaller assignments towards the beginning of the semester were very useful, as was the QLab skills quiz. The Deiorio and the Music as a Chariot readings were both great for engagement out of class, and I wish we had been assigned more of them. Scoring the Jekyll and Hyde script multiple times was also great.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
-Ethan knows his craft and is able to teach it in a variety of ways using hands-on technology as well as with readings and at-home assignments.
-OH are helpful for getting up to speed if behind or with asking questions re: DAW or QLab use.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Great. This is the only class I have this semester that I feel unstressed to speak up anytime. I like the one-by-one display of weekly assignments and the following peer feedback session. This section really opens up the floor for discussion.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Course is well constructed

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
-QLab tutorials were very helpful. I would suggest assigning them as homework rather than going through it as a class. It was difficult to grasp until I actually did it myself
-The variety in the assignments was engaging - using an existing story, using only sound, making speaker plots, etc.
-The midterm was a great checkpoint for my technical skills

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The spatialization of sound, especially in live performance was challenging and inspiring.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: More readings and out of class work! More skills quizzes! The topics were all incredibly stimulating, and because we were covering such a broad field of knowledge, I felt we could have been given more of a challenge to chew on in order to cover more of that field. More listening opportunities might also have been useful, maybe a mandatory field trip to a show or having student presentations on shows they'd been to?

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
-Music creation and sound adaptation were stimulating aspects of the class.
-Sound designing for scripts like Jekyll & Hyde was a fun and interesting experience.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: In-class discussions and feedback from my classmates. Also, I like the context-fixed creative assignments that allow me to apply some techniques in several unexpected situations, such as transformation moments in the hyde script.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: The book is very educational

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text:
-The student presentations of the assignments many of the weeks taking all of class was not very stimulating. I felt disengaged after a few people went. If it were a shorter amount of class time or only a few people present each week, I think it would be more engaging
-I would have appreciated more instructor lectures on the technical and conceptual decisions in sound design, especially in the beginning of the semester
-Bringing us into the theater for the show was super engaging and I learned a lot being in the actual theater space

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: It's good! A course that is unique and teaches unique invaluable skills and asks you to think and make creatively. So grateful for this course.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text:
-Good for theatrical sound design, as in the title!
-You learn what you put into it. If heavily invested, a lot. If less so, then you will still learn a good amount and it will change your perception of theatre when you experience it live.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: JUST TAKE IT!
